intro: Vassobia atropoides, commonly known as the black-eyed Susan, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads that consist of both ray and disk florets. The plant typically grows to a height of 1 to 3 feet, with lance-shaped leaves and bright yellow flowers that contrast with its dark centers. It thrives in full sun and well-drained soil, making it a popular choice for gardens and natural landscapes. Vassobia atropoides is also known for its ability to attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies.
